Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2014 07:02AM tryn2staycalm wrote: Carolben - Sorry that chemo is sucking life out of you.  Hope the neupogen shots work their magic!  I'm doing well on the trial but lots more hot flashes BUT I do think my breathing is some better.  I noticed climbing stairs doesn't leave me so breathless now too.  Hoping I'm getting the real deal and not the placebo and that is why.  Was back in to see onco and trial team yesterday and had all my blood work, and my 3 ECG's 2 mins apart and everything is still looking good.  Only I had a major blood sugar low (insulin dependant diabetic)  just after walking out of lab and had to sit and volunteer brought me juice and food till I started to come back up.  After finishing all the visits my oncology nurse came running back into the room and asked kind of funny " Are you ok? "  I said yes I am now.  She said I just got some of your lab work and your blood glucose was only 2.2 ( different reading system in Canada) and it should be 6.  Anything under 3 and you can go into a coma.  Then my oncologist came back in saying same thing basically.  They made me stay and got my more juice and waited then tested my bs again and I was back up to 5.3.  I think I kind of shocked them that I was still sitting but I know the signed of having a low.  Severe weakness and shakes and sweats and this time dizzy too.  Anyways was a full day as I was there for hours but had a good friend with me so time passed well.  Hope everyone has a nice weekend and feels well enough to enjoy it.  Here in Canada it is a long weekend our "Civic Holiday".  Hugs to all and holding hands in our circle to all that need it. Cathy

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 06:22PM tryn2staycalm wrote: I'm told that even with clear nodes it does not rule out that an odd cancer cell could have gotten into the blood stream and that leaves you at risk for mets.  The larger the invasive tumor and the higher the grade (aggressive) the larger the risk.  This is why my onco told me that a IDC tumor over 2cm would normally be treated with chemo (according to guidelines).  This tracks down the odd cells that may have escaped and kills them before they can spread.  This still does not rule out that it has already mets.  Therefore it would be best to be caught early stage and that is why the more tests the better the odds.  I'm still learning but from what I've heard thats how I have interpreted it. Cathy

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2010 08:58AM tryn2staycalm wrote: Carey I got a call from my surgeon today, finally.  She told me that it is insitu.  Due to my other health concerns, diabetes, high blood pressure, etc. she wants to do my "generous lumpectomy" with just a local but can't do lymph nodes at the same time.  We decided to go ahead with the local and it will be faster and then start testing and then I will find out if I need to do the nodes.  She is putting me down for Wed. afternoon but it has to be confirmed by the hospital yet.  At least it is finally starting to move from the "waiting game".  I read your profile and I wish you all the best and I hope you are well very soon and get to know the joy of motherhood in the very near future.  I just have a reg doctor deal with my diabetes here.  If I want more then I would have to go to a diabetic clinic.  Maybe now that it is finally going to get moving I will get my bs better controlled.  If not then I will go to the clinic (another half hour drive).  My employer is also very good about me taking time off for this.  I've been training my "helper" to do a lot of my work while I'm gone.  But I'll be back ASAP.    Take Care and talk to you soon, and ty. Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 03:58AM - edited Jul 12, 2010 04:00AM by tryn2staycalm Michelle I just got back from the Lake and yes it is delightful.  A couple of my best friends are right beside my trailer and it is so relaxing.  Yes it sounds that your a lady who has her future in controll.. thats a good thing.  I wish you the best.  Its still a waiting game for me, getting all the tests in after surgury, and now they changed my surgury from Wed to Friday.  I'm trying to make use of my time getting as prepared as I can.  Shopping, housecleaning, yard work, laundry, as well as work.  I do not do "sick" well.  I don't like to be "restricted" on my actions and I hate asking others for help.  I'm sure that sounds familar to a few of you.  One of my neigbours at the Lake is a RN and has taken special training in Diabetes.  She went over my readings and insulin with me and tells me that it is important that I keep going up in insullin (slowly) till I get it where it should be so that healing takes place after surgury.  She agreed that I will most likely be able to reduce it when things calm down. Cathy

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2014 10:55PM tryn2staycalm wrote: Purple 32 - First of all a warm compassionate hug for you.  So sorry you have reason to bring you here and please feel most welcome.  I have only been dx stage IV as of May 2/14 so I know the overwhelming pain and heartache your having along with your husband.  Do NOT give up,  you or him, there is so much they can try and if he responds well to the treatment he could live years if he gets the mets under control and there is also no reason to be in pain now.  Insist on something for pain.  I too have applied for CPP Disability as I am Canadian.  Get the forms from your nearest gov office and get the paperwork done ASAP and get the doctor to fill his out ASAP and do not wait to file your portion send it off first and doctors can follow. Do not mail but take to the gov office and they should go over it with you rather than taking days in the mail they will fax it in or at least they did for me.  I would say to get it started quickly as your claim will start for back pay as soon as you file.  It is pretty much a given that he will be accepted without too much delay.  Hope you find peace soon as you both start to accept and cope with this dx and then I hope you both don't forget to still enjoy life.  Don't let this terrible disease steal all your good days!  Believe me you will get there, it just takes some time.  I know first hand. Cathy

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 04:34PM tryn2staycalm wrote: calamtykel-  I wasn't given anything to upset my stomach.  Only took a few tyenol 3 the day of and day after surgery and that was over 3 weeks ago.  My nausea only started about a week or 10 days ago.  Its not severe but on and off slightly, but daily, until I get in a car and then if I'm traveling (to my cancer clinic 3 1/2 hours of winding roads) it gets very severe.  I have to take gravol to be able to take it.  I had my US on my kidneys and liver today.  Another US booked for Wed. on pelvis and back to surgeon tomorrow.  I know it seems CT scans and MRI are normal to look for mets but I have had none.  The questionnaire from the cancer center asked about nausea and thats why my onco booked me for these ultrasounds.   I know that the pictures are via computer quickly but a written report that they type up (I know from my breast ultra sound that found the cancer) comes in after the pictures.  It states what he finds in the pictures and/ or scan.  He will also give his opinion of what needs to be done as mine said he recommended a biopsy and in his opinion it was a malignant tumor and should be treated as one unless proved otherwise.  I do agree that all this becomes overwhelming.  All the tests and all the waiting.  You are NOT alone having every little thing freaking you out.  I think its quite normal to worry about what we do not know about with this disease.  We "what if it" and it keeps us awake at night and its on our minds the minute we wake.  Somehow we will get thru it.  Somehow we gain the strength we must.  I hope you get good results so you can relax soon.  Maybe when we get over all the tests and move on to treatment.  Hang in there, I'm on the ride with you and so are a lot of other gals. Cathy

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2015 07:55AM tryn2staycalm wrote: Hi Ladies, As promised I am back to update on this thread. It turns out my MO was correct with my allergic reactions to my Taxol treatment. Latest scans showed that the Taxol was shrinking both the lung and liver mets however my bone mets were still progressing the worst being in my spine. To target this I underwent bone radiation witch helped a lot. My break from treatment (gong moment when done Radiation) was very short lived however. I finished bone Rads on Wed. last week and Thursday I was taken from my home by EMS after having a fall and not being able to get up and a lot of side effects similar to a stroke. I was transferred to my cancer center where I found out that my mets had spread once again this time to my brain. Although we all know this shortens my life expectancy I do continue to fight all I can. Wish everyone the best in there battle. Cathy
